programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Dive in Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Koishikawa – Historic Charm and Industry Nurtured by Water
programme.desc: Koishikawa is a residential area in the city center that is home to a botanical garden and a temple associated with the Edo shogunate. As we explore, we discover a legacy of printing and bookbinding.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: KABUKI KOOL
programme.desc: Unswerving Devotion: The Japanese Twenty-Four Examples of Filial Piety. Kataoka Ainosuke is our guide to a play featuring a kabuki princess in a story of warring clans and the magic of a sacred helmet. Princess Yaegaki holding the sacred helmet and surrounded by the magical foxes. With the help of the magic of the foxes, she goes to save her lover's life.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Considering Our Future Through Dinosaur Research: Kobayashi Yoshitsugu / Paleontologist / Professor, Hokkaido University
programme.desc: In June 2025, Kobayashi Yoshitsugu published a trailblazing paper, illuminating the evolutionary process of large tyrannosaurs. He explains how such research helps us consider the future of humanity.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: non-loosening bolts.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Wastewater Research for Public Health: Kitajima Masaaki / Project Professor, Research Center for Water Environment Technology, The University of Tokyo
programme.desc: In 2020, Kitajima Masaaki published the world's first paper on how the spread of COVID-19 could be tracked by monitoring wastewater. He talks about making an impact on infectious disease control.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony
programme.desc: Winter in Japan's oldest private herb garden in Uda, Nara Prefecture. As fallen leaves and withered grass cover the ground, the search begins for treasures hidden beneath the frozen soil.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: We journey to a sacred mountain where pilgrims are purifying themselves in a waterfall before moving on. Some of them have even brought along offerings ... and it turns out they have something to prove.

programme.title: Science View
programme.desc: Japan's traditional papercraft, origami, has come to be used in engineering, as researchers observe insects and other specimens to develop "crease patterns" that can be utilized in diverse fields.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS
programme.desc: Much of the stonework supporting Japan's terraced fields is in danger of collapse. There's an urgent need to train new stonemasons to carry out repairs. Kaneko Reo runs workshops around the country.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Sushi's New Era: Challenges Transform Japan's Food Culture
programme.desc: Sushi is enjoying a global boom, but it's a different story back in Japan. Dwindling catches of local fish and intense competition for foreign customers have polarized the domestic industry. High-end restaurants and popular chains are thriving, but local restaurants have been pushed to the brink. Some experts worry the future of sushi culture is at risk. But in some corners, efforts are underway to preserve the traditional cuisine and modernize its appeal. We take a close look at the new era of sushi. Guests: Suzuki Makoto (Representative, Japan Sustainable Seafood Society) Chidui Yuki (Sushi expert/chef)

programme.title: Japanology Plus
programme.desc: *First broadcast on November 7, 2024. The spaces under Japan's elevated train tracks are now being used not just for pubs and restaurants but in many new ways, in various urban settings. We explore the economic and community benefits.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony #5
programme.desc: In Uda, discover Japan's oldest private medicinal herb garden, where the natural landscape from 300 years ago is preserved in a botanical time capsule, a sanctuary of the local culture and history.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: In the pleasure quarter of Yoshiwara, a high-ranking courtesan tends to a patron, while a jester attempts to entertain with an eccentric costume -- hinting at the Edo townspeople's affinity for cosplay.

programme.title: Japan Railway Journal
programme.sub-title: Must-see Railway News: The Latter Half of 2025

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Taketa: Onsen Bathing Old and New
programme.desc: People in Japan love bathing in hot springs, or onsen. And since the old days, it has been common for people to check into residential hot-spring inns for extended stays to boost their health, heal their aches and regain their well-being. This style of onsen therapeutics is known as Tōji. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Kyle Card travels to Taketa City in Oita Prefecture to discover a contemporary style of Tōji therapy where visitors can recover their energy while enjoying the majestic natural environment along with some of the world's finest carbonated hot springs.

programme.sub-title: The Global Rise of Japanese Literature: Tejima Yuki, Literary Translator
programme.desc: Why is Japanese literature gaining international acclaim? Tejima Yuki, literary translator of "Totto-chan, The Sequel," shares her view.

programme.title: Dig More Japan
programme.desc: In Japan's snow country, harsh winters aren't just endured, but enjoyed. Let's dig a little deeper. programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef
programme.sub-title: Master Chef's Class: Chef Kuwakino's Rice-Based Plant Cuisine
programme.desc: Join Harry Sugiyama and chef Kuwakino for a fresh, fast master class in Veggie-full Japanese cooking, where rice takes center stage. Let's get cooking!

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Adapting Anime Costumes for Live-Action: Nakahara Sachiko / Stylist and Costume Designer
programme.desc: Nakahara Sachiko translates the looks of popular Japanese anime and manga characters into costumes for live-action adaptations. She talks about making an impact on the global stage.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.desc: Join us as we learn about life at the Otowasan Kannonji Temple through 24 terms from the solar calendar. First, we follow the nuns on the day of Risshun. They enjoy colorful neko-mochi rice cakes, creating unique variations by adding unusual ingredients. Then they celebrate Girls' Day with a special tea ceremony on the day of Usui.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Napping Boy Dreams of Monsters
programme.desc: When a little boy's nap is disturbed by a bad dream, his mother comes to his rescue. What was terrorizing him? We examine a print that shows how much the Edo townspeople cherished their kids.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Aging Well: The Most Private Challenge
programme.desc: Japanese people are increasingly living longer lives, but the change is not always a welcome one. For many, the progression into old age, and the accompanying decline in bodily functions, results in continence issues. Many are reluctant to acknowledge the problem or accept outside help on such an intensely private matter. We asked experts how carers and loved ones can support people dealing with toileting issues, and consider how the elderly themselves can embrace a positive shift in perspective to get the most out of their final stage of life. Guests: Gondo Yasuyuki (Professor, Graduate School of Human Sciences, The University of Osaka), Urata Katsumi (Certified Nurse in Wound, Ostomy and Continence Nursing with Advanced Practice Authorization)

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: At a Huge Thrift Store in Saitama
programme.desc: Bargain-hunters and people decluttering their homes flock to a huge thrift store near Tokyo. For three days, we asked customers what drew them to this place filled with an array of second-hand goods.

programme.title: Trails to Oishii Tokyo
programme.desc: Wagyu captivates food lovers worldwide with fine marbling, melt-in-the-mouth texture, and rich aroma. Join us as we explore strict cattle management and the dishes that highlight wagyu's appeal. Reporter: Safiya Quinley

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Bonsai: Harmonious Beauty and Eternal Life
programme.desc: Bonsai came from China over 1000 years ago, evolving into a unique artform. In Kyoto, the emphasis is on beauty and harmony in space, the same aesthetic that flows through ikebana and the Way of Tea.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Sushi's New Era: Challenges Transform Japan's Food Culture
programme.desc: Sushi is enjoying a global boom, but it's a different story back in Japan. Dwindling catches of local fish and intense competition for foreign customers have polarized the domestic industry. High-end restaurants and popular chains are thriving, but local restaurants have been pushed to the brink. Some experts worry the future of sushi culture is at risk. But in some corners, efforts are underway to preserve the traditional cuisine and modernize its appeal. We take a close look at the new era of sushi. Guests: Suzuki Makoto (Representative, Japan Sustainable Seafood Society) Chidui Yuki (Sushi expert/chef)

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Halting Desertification with Waste: Oyama Shuichi / Professor, Research Institute for Humanity and Nature / Kyoto University Graduate School
programme.desc: The majority of Niger, in Africa, is occupied by the Sahara, and desertification is a major problem. Oyama Shuichi introduces his method of increasing vegetation using household waste.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony #5
programme.desc: In Uda, discover Japan's oldest private medicinal herb garden, where the natural landscape from 300 years ago is preserved in a botanical time capsule, a sanctuary of the local culture and history.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: In the pleasure quarter of Yoshiwara, a high-ranking courtesan tends to a patron, while a jester attempts to entertain with an eccentric costume -- hinting at the Edo townspeople's affinity for cosplay.

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.desc: Despite earthquakes and isolation, the people of Akusekijima Island work to uphold local traditions, including the mysterious Boze deities. A new generation is helping to keep those traditions alive.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hello there! It's me, Tama. Don't mind me, I just saw a hole and wanted to cool my paws in it. Looks like Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are preparing their annual dried persimmons. So tasty! So sweet! But it takes weeks before they're ready! I don't know if I can wait that long!

programme.title: Japanology Plus
programme.desc: *First broadcast on November 7, 2024. The spaces under Japan's elevated train tracks are now being used not just for pubs and restaurants but in many new ways, in various urban settings. We explore the economic and community benefits.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Awaji Island: Mythical Birthplace of Japan
programme.desc: Awaji Island is the largest island in the Seto Inland Sea. From ancient times, Awaji has been known as "Japan's Foodstore," and local fish have, down the years, been presented to the Imperial Court. The island is also proud of its connection to the legend of the two gods, Izanagi and Izanami, who gave birth to Japan. The story of Japan's origins describes how the gods passed the country on to the people. Awaji Island is where it all began.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.desc: Influential ukiyo-e artist Utagawa Hiroshige's "100 Famous Views of Edo", a series of prints encoding his view of the changing face of Japan.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.sub-title: The Manyoshu Edition / Episode I: Love
programme.desc: The Manyoshu is the oldest extant anthology of Japanese poetry. Through poems presented in both manga and a modern setting, we glimpse sentiments from centuries ago.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Enormous floats called neputa paraded through the streets are the highlight of Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri in Hirosaki, Aomori Prefecture. The floats are decorated with vibrant images painted on washi paper. Some floats feature wireframe 3D figures. For most of the floats new art is produced every year, and preparations begin months in advance. This 300-year-old tradition began as a way to ward off drowsiness and keep people focused on farm work in the heat of summer.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: The Imperial Palace
programme.desc: At the Imperial Palace, thoughtful preparation and meticulous attention to detail contribute to a warm welcome for distinguished guests. Join us as we go behind the scenes.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: Avalanches occur suddenly, damaging houses and injuring people. Many of the avalanches that occurred in Yamanashi Prefecture in 2014 took place in locations where avalanches are uncommon. We now know that many of these were "slab avalanches," in which a slab of surface layer snow is dislodged. How and why did these slab avalanches occur? We'll look at the latest efforts to better understand the underlying mechanisms, and the steps being taken to save lives.

programme.desc: Kochi Prefecture / Miyamae Yoshiyuki (Fashion designer) Kochi's Sunday market features around 500 stalls with fixed locations. Miyamae contemplates how communication has contributed to its longevity.

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.sub-title: Life on the Edge – Takin, Bhutan
programme.desc: High in the Himalayas lives a legendary beast with the body of a cow and the head of a goat. Listed as a vulnerable species, the takin now faces a deadly disease spreading through its mountain home.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.desc: Seto Inland Sea is the largest body of water of its kind in Japan, with over 700 islands in it. The Great Seto Bridge offers beautiful views of the sea and connects islands across 9,368m of bridge span. The reflection of the sunset on the shallow coastal waters creates a mystical landscape. See the sights of the Seto Inland Sea through time-lapse photography.

programme.title: Design Ah neo
programme.desc: Design is fun! Design feels good! Cutting-edge images and music guide children to enjoy exploring the ideas and tweaks in the designs all around us. An episode on Sandwiches.

programme.title: Mitateru-phose: Let's Change Perspectives!
programme.desc: This program employs "mitateru," a Japanese technique, to inspire children's imagination by encouraging them to view objects differently and develop their unique perspectives and creativity. (#4)

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The Professionals
programme.sub-title: kensuke ushio: Letting the Music Just Be There
programme.desc: The soundtrack composer for hit anime shows and movies, this musician is driving the world wild with his music. As he starts on a new anime, we follow the struggle from which his unique sound emerges.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.desc: Influential ukiyo-e artist Utagawa Hiroshige's "100 Famous Views of Edo", a series of prints encoding his view of the changing face of Japan.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.sub-title: The Manyoshu Edition / Episode I: Love
programme.desc: The Manyoshu is the oldest extant anthology of Japanese poetry. Through poems presented in both manga and a modern setting, we glimpse sentiments from centuries ago.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Enormous floats called neputa paraded through the streets are the highlight of Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri in Hirosaki, Aomori Prefecture. The floats are decorated with vibrant images painted on washi paper. Some floats feature wireframe 3D figures. For most of the floats new art is produced every year, and preparations begin months in advance. This 300-year-old tradition began as a way to ward off drowsiness and keep people focused on farm work in the heat of summer.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The Imperial Palace
programme.desc: At the Imperial Palace, thoughtful preparation and meticulous attention to detail contribute to a warm welcome for distinguished guests. Join us as we go behind the scenes.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: Avalanches occur suddenly, damaging houses and injuring people. Many of the avalanches that occurred in Yamanashi Prefecture in 2014 took place in locations where avalanches are uncommon. We now know that many of these were "slab avalanches," in which a slab of surface layer snow is dislodged. How and why did these slab avalanches occur? We'll look at the latest efforts to better understand the underlying mechanisms, and the steps being taken to save lives.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Kochi Prefecture / Miyamae Yoshiyuki (Fashion designer) Kochi's Sunday market features around 500 stalls with fixed locations. Miyamae contemplates how communication has contributed to its longevity.

programme.title: Inside the Los Angeles Wildfire Recovery
programme.desc: Nearly a year after a devastating Los Angeles wildfire, recovery has not been equal. Survivors face disaster capitalism and hard choices, while fighting to protect their community and their future.

programme.title: Broadcasters' Eye
programme.sub-title: Clearing Snow Above the Clouds: Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route
programme.desc: 【Toyama Television Broadcasting】 Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route sees some of the world's heaviest snowfall. Follow the snowplowing crew as they spend 50 days carving a 30 km road, shaping snow walls and training the next generation.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Frozen food is extremely popular in Japan. A supermarket may have a dedicated section with hundreds of frozen items. While pasta is the most popular frozen food, options range from chopped vegetables to sushi. One key to the success of frozen food is flash freezing, which limits damage to food cells during the freezing process, thus preserving taste and texture. Flash freezing is a great way to make food last longer. We review the history of Japanese frozen food and introduce recent innovations.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: Ran lives with wakame divers and watches over their daily work. If neighboring cat Fukusuke comes over, Ran goes on high alert. Pei lives at an inn near the lakeshore and is popular with customers.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: CYCLE AROUND JAPAN Highlights
programme.desc: We visit the Goto Islands on Japan's western tip, meeting people with hospitality, like a couple passing on the history of hidden Christians and islanders trying to preserve their small community.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Rockie is taught by her mother that fun sounds can be found by listening well. She goes out with her buddies to look for fun sounds, and is thrilled at the variety of sounds she hears, such as the flapping of wings and sneezing. Educational theme: The preciousness of life.

programme.title: Texico
programme.desc: Learn the principles of programming without even touching a computer in this new-style education program. Unique animated characters assist in the fun and lucid introduction of 5 core programming processes: analysis, combination, generalization, abstraction and simulation.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Erfurt, a city in Thuringia near the center of Germany, traces its roots back to the 8th century. By the 11th century, it had developed into a major crossroads uniting trade and culture across Europe.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: EKIBEN JAPAN
programme.sub-title: Northern Waters and Woodlands Nurtured by Fishermen
programme.desc: An ekiben from Hokkaido's Hidaka region uses kombu and shellfish. It's a bento filled with the bounty of the sea nurtured by northern fishermen.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Oyatsu: Sweets and Treats for Everyday People
programme.desc: Kyoto has many stores specializing in traditional snacks and treats, called Oyatsu, that are also used in festivals. Some purveyors continue to use age-old ingredients and methods, and the lines outside their stores are proof of their popularity. Discover the sweets and treats that embody the everyday wisdom of old.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #4 How to make explanations using photos and other materials
programme.desc: This episode is about using materials to express oneself in a way that's easy to understand. Nu Nu Aung, from Myanmar, moved to Japan 9 months ago and works at a property management company. Every day, she receives training in Japanese and learns more about real estate. In one week's time, Nu Nu Aung will make a presentation in Japanese about areas of Tokyo. To prepare, she will role-play and learn from experts about how to make explanations using photos and other materials.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: With a falling birthrate, school closures are on the rise in Japan, and things like desks and chairs have no place to go. Doi Kenji upcycles these discards into stylish and unique interior items.
